issues: Missing BUN value (required for BUN/creatinine ratio assessment)
Body mass index (BMI) missing, limiting BMI‑creatinine correlation analysis
Lab timestamps unavailable, limiting assessment of lab staleness
Patient is hemodynamically unstable (MAP 49.3 mmHg), raising concern for contrast‑induced nephropathy despite low eGFR
recommendations: Proceed with emergent contrast‑enhanced CT/CTA as per protocol, given the life‑threatening thoracic aortic injury.
Obtain missing laboratory values (BUN, potassium, BMI) as soon as feasible to allow full renal risk assessment.
Ensure hemodynamic stabilization (e.g., blood pressure support) before contrast administration if possible, or consider alternative imaging if stabilization cannot be achieved promptly.
Document discussion of renal risk, obtain informed consent, and note the patient’s hemodynamic status in the imaging order.
Monitor serum creatinine and eGFR post‑contrast to detect any acute kidney injury, especially given the hypotension.
Consider post‑contrast hydration protocol if clinically appropriate.
